title: EPA PCE: Workshops
text:
Welcome to the Final Project
Welcome to the EPA101 Policy Analysis Final Group Project! This project is an opportunity for you to apply the policy analysis skills you have developed throughout the course. You will work in groups to analyze a policy problem, consider alternative solutions, evaluate them against specific criteria, and make a recommendation to a client.
Below is a table outlining the components of the Final Group Project and what you need to do for each part.








Component
Description




a) Problem Statement
i) A clear, concise problem statementii) Discussion of evidence and reasoning supporting the problem statement you have chosen- Formulate a clear and concise statement of the policy problem you are addressing.- Provide evidence and reasoning supporting it.


b) Alternatives
- Identify 3-4 distinct policy alternatives, each of which plausibly addresses the stated problem.- Develop 3-4 viable policy alternatives that could potentially solve the problem you’ve identified.


c) Criteria
i) At least 3 distinct criteria to compare the policy alternativesii) Discussion of how to measure or evaluate each criterioniii) How the criteria relate to broader objectives and values- Establish evaluation criteria and explain their relevance.


d) Project the Outcomes
i) Describe projected outcomes for each alternative on each criterionii) An analysis matrix (alternatives vs. criteria)iii) Explain how you arrived at each projectioniv) Discuss key stakeholders and their potential responses


e) Confront the Tradeoffs
i) Describe tradeoffs between alternatives given your criteria and projected outcomesii) Explain the reasoning used to resolve those tradeoffs to reach your recommendation


f) Uncertainty
i) Describe important sources of uncertainty and assumptions madeii) Discuss how changes in assumptions could affect your recommended alternative


g) Recommendation
- Recommend one of the alternatives evaluated and clearly state that recommendation in the memo’s first paragraph.- Make a clear and concise recommendation based on your analysis.


h) Client
- Identify a client: an organization, agency, or public official with an interest in the policy problem.Note: It is not necessary to communicate or interact with the client for EPA101.

title: EPA PCE: Workshops
text:
Formulate a clear and concise statement of the policy problem you are addressing.





Provide evidence and reasoning that support the importance and relevance of the problem you have identified.






Identify 3-4 distinct policy alternatives, each of which plausibly addresses the stated problem.







Establish at least three distinct criteria that you will use to evaluate and compare the policy alternatives.





Explain how you will measure or evaluate each criterion.





Discuss how the criteria relate to the broader objectives and values that motivate your work in this policy area.








For each policy alternative, describe the projected outcomes with respect to each criterion.





Create an analysis matrix where:

Rows represent the alternatives
Columns represent the criteria
Cells contain a summary of the projected outcomes






Explain the evidence, frameworks, and reasoning used to arrive at each projected outcome.





Discuss key stakeholders and analyze how they may respond to each policy alternative.








Describe the tradeoffs between the policy alternatives based on your criteria and projected outcomes.





Explain how you resolved the tradeoffs to arrive at your recommended alternative.








Identify important sources of uncertainty in your analysis and state any assumptions made.





Discuss how your recommendation might change if the assumptions were altered.






Recommend one of the alternatives you evaluated, and clearly state that recommendation in the memo’s first paragraph.





Identify a client: An organization, agency, or public official with an interest in the policy problem.

Note: It is not necessary to communicate or interact with the client for EPA101.

title: Schedule
text:
Workshop Schedule
Welcome to the EPA101 Workshop Schedule page. This schedule outlines the key dates, workshops, and deliverables for the course. Some workshops are focused on collaborative learning and do not have associated deliverables, while others coincide with important assignment due dates. Use this schedule to manage your time effectively and ensure you’re prepared for each class.
Please note that not all workshops have deliverables due. Workshops without deliverables are designed to help you develop your project through collaborative discussions and activities. Make sure to attend each workshop prepared to engage with the material and your peers.
